summary: This paper presents a method for spatial identification of objects for bionic upper limb prostheses using an optoelectronic module and neural network algorithms. Engineers should care because it enhances the accuracy of prosthetic grip types based on object shapes, improving user experience and functionality.
key_contribution: Integration of spatial identification of object shapes with myographic signal analysis for improved grip-type recognition in bionic prostheses.
problem_description: The challenge of accurately interpreting user intentions through noisy and variable EMG signals in bionic hand prostheses.

method.approach: The method utilizes an optoelectronic module to capture images of objects and classifies them using a neural network. It correlates the identified object shape with myographic signals to determine the appropriate grip type for the prosthesis.
algorithm_steps: 1. Capture images of objects using the ESP32-CAM.
2. Preprocess images to standardize size and format.
3. Feed images into the MobileNetV2 neural network.
4. Classify the object shape into predefined categories (spherical, rectangular, cylindrical).
5. Analyze myographic signals to determine user intent.
6. Match identified shape with appropriate grip type.
7. Execute grip type based on the classification results.
method.input: Digital images of objects (240x240 pixels) captured by the ESP32-CAM.
method.output: Identified object shape, grip type, coordinates of the object in the camera's field of view, and dimensions in the X and Y planes.

datasets: 235 color images of basic shapes (spherical, rectangular, cylindrical)
benchmarks.improvement: Achieved 89.2% accuracy with a processing time of 2 ms per image.

use_this_when: Developing low-cost bionic prostheses that require object shape recognition.
Integrating machine learning for real-time object identification in prosthetic devices.
Enhancing user experience in prosthetics through improved grip type accuracy.
dont_use_when: High precision is required beyond the capabilities of the proposed method.
Complex object shapes that exceed the training dataset's scope.
When additional computational resources are available for more complex algorithms.

implementation_guide.pseudocode_hint: image = capture_image(); shape = classify_shape(image); grip_type = determine_grip(shape, myographic_signal);
gotchas: Ensure proper lighting conditions for image capture.
Be aware of the camera's resolution limitations.
Training dataset should include diverse object shapes to improve accuracy.

limitations: Limited to basic shapes defined in the training set.
Performance may degrade with complex object shapes.
Dependent on the quality of the captured images.
open_questions: How can the system be improved to handle more complex object shapes?
What additional sensors could enhance the accuracy of grip type recognition?
